awd_titl_txt: The Interaction of Pyroclastic Density Currents with the Atmosphere & Landscapes: Integrating Experiments and Computational Approaches for Validation & Examination of Entrainment
awd_abstract_narration:
Pyroclastic density currents (PDCs) are among the most dangerous and unpredictable volcanic phenomena. These currents threaten over 200 million people worldwide. The currents are generated when mixtures of explosively erupted material are greater density than the atmosphere and are characterized by high velocities and temperatures making them particularly dangerous for people and infrastructure. Yet direct observation of the internal workings of these currents have been confounded by the difficulty in predicting their occurrence, hazardous conditions, and opacity limiting observation of the internal dynamics. These currents often have heterogeneous particle concentrations in a single current, so that a solitary event will have a range of spatial-temporally evolving and overlapping physical processes. Ultimately these currents are driven by the density contrast between the current and the atmosphere, and any process (such as air entrainment or erosion of the substrate) that changes the particle concentration of the current will significantly impact their dynamics. In this way, PDC are sensitive to and communicate with the atmosphere and landscape through which they travel. However, there is a distinct gap in knowledge concerning entrainment and erosion in PDC. The proposed work will conduct large-scale experiments and numerical simulations to determine internal physical processes in PDC. This information will be used to improve our numerical simulation tools to better understand the hazards from these flows.

This proposed work will integrate the results of several styles of experiments that emphasize end member processes and scales important for PDC dynamics. Select experimental results will be used to validate the numerical simulation of these processes, while other experiments will explore two important physical processes in PDC, entrainment and erosion. We will address the following inter-related goals: 1. Validate fluid dynamics models to encompass the particle concentration and fluid dynamics environment experienced throughout an evolving PDC, 2. Determine the entrainment efficiency of PDC and relate this to thermal evolution and transport capacity, 3. Assess the ability of entrainment to generate self-fluidization, 4. Assess bed forces from both particle and gas sources and relate these to the erosive capacity, 5. Generate modules for entrainment and erosion that can be incorporated into any numerical approach with a particular emphasis on rapid, end-member models to aid in hazard assessment, and 6. Develop a "Fluid Dynamics of PDC" video/lesson plan that highlights the visualizations from both experiments and simulations to educate students on the range of fluid dynamics in PDC.

por.por_cntn:
Pyroclastic density currents (PDCs) are among the most dangerous and unpredictable volcanic phenomena. Direct observation of the internal workings of these currents have been confounded by the difficulty in predicting their occurrence, hazardous conditions, and opacity limiting observation of the internal dynamics. The work funded by this project combined information from experiments and numerical simulations to better describe the transport of these currents and their internal dynamics. This project also funded a series of benchmark exercises aimed at validating the numerical simulations under end-member conditions so that uncertainty from these models can be better understood. Ultimately this work improved our understanding of the controls on flow runout and the dynamic pressures that can cause damage.

  This work examined the multiphase physics of the three regimes that co-exists in PDC: the dilute turbulent regime, the intermediate regime with mesoscale particle clusters and the dense granular regime. First we recognized that the dense or dilute regime dominate PDC’s motion and the intermediate regime is dominated by transient processes, where instabilities take the form of mesoscale particle clusters. As a result, we classified known PDC deposits throughout the world and showed that their dominant transport mechanism was either dense or dilute dominated.

  In PDCs, permeability is an important property that actively controls the behavior of the dense regime by retaining fluid pressure, which ultimately decreases the solid confining pressure (active in debris flows and pyroclastic density currents). A portion of our work investigated the microphysical properties of volcanic mixtures and their influence on the media permeability in order to theoretically predict the permeability of natural volcanic mixtures. We showed that their permeability can be predicted by using an equivalent diameter. While permeability is the primary factor contributing to the pore-fluid retention in fluid-particle flows, large-scale experiments and highly resolved simulations reveal another important process: the shear-induced pressure advection that follows flow dilation, also known as pore-pressure feedback. This process is not restricted to dilation as it also plays a large role during compaction, as demonstrated in a comparison study between experiments and simulations. We also investigated fluidization behavior and described a self-fluidization mechanism associated with meso-scale cluster sedimentation that results in enhanced mobility of these currents.

Furthermore, we investigated the rheology of gas-particle flows in the dense regime, a regime where the frictional particle-particle interactions dominate the momentum loss. We revealed the strong influence of pore pressure diffusion on frictional flow properties through drag-induced dilation. Simultaneously, we investigated how the dense granular regime interacts with a rough substrate, and proposed a correlation between the frictional stresses imposed on the substrate and the granular temperature (granular velocity fluctuations) of the flow.

  Finally, we conducted a validation exercise for a multiphase modeling approach comparing both dense and dilute experiments. The latest is the first international validation of these granular flows, which enables all PDC models to be tested against a dataset obtained from a large-scale experiment.

  Most of the advances of our understanding of PDCs associated with this grant have implications for a wide range of volcanic and non-volcanic geophysical flows, such as debris flows, rock, snow and submarine avalanches. This work resulted in 8 publications and the resulting validated multiphase model yielded insight into granular sorting in these flows that helps in the interpretation of past eruptions, as well as a better understanding of fluidization, entrainment and transport to prepare for future eruption scenarios.
